Navbar

To create a navbar, use the nav element and put your links within a list element. Some example code below:

(Insert basic navbar code here)

This will style the navbar based on the width of the browser:

  • In small browsers, one list item will be displayed per row.
  • In medium browsers, two list items will be displayed per row.
  • In large browsers, all list items will be displayed on a single row.

Add the current_page class to note which page the user has currently selected. This will use the $nav-current-page-color to color that text. Otherwise, the framework uses $nav-text-color to color the text.

Here are all of the variables associated with navbar:

(Put in block) $nav-background-color: $nav-element-background-color: $nav-text-color: $nav-current-page-color: $nav-font-family:

Content (aka Card/Panel/Tile)

Whatever you want to call it, these add a style onto the element that lets it pop out, as if you put the content on a card and placed it on the page. You can use the content-primary, content-secondary, or content-tertiary class to set the background color to the primary, secondary or tertiary color.

(insert code here)

You can modify some of the Sass variables to control the look and feel of these elements.
